reviews.review_text: Being a huge fan of the CoH series and a top tier player I aim to give a balanced review and dispell the undeserved negative user reviews. Please note this is my first proper review and any feedback is appreciated =).  Do not be fooled by the hateful meta critic user reviews that score the game incredibly low. These are all largely due to patriotic Russians who exaggerate and claim the devlopers are Nazis as the campagin portrays the Soviet Union in a bad light. One such scene they are particularly angry about is when retreating russian soldiers are being shot down by their own machine guns. Granted Relic could have portrayed these horros of war better so that they could not be misinterpreted but they didn't set out to shame an entire nation. What the campagin really shows is the the story of the war through one man's eyes, showing the great bravey of the typical russian soldier under a ruthless poltical system and an equally terrifying invading German army. Which probably took more courage to do than that of soldiers from other countries.   For those who worry about Pay to win I can assure you it's entire nonsense. None of the new content is aimed to give players an edge in multiplayer. Obviously when it is first introduced there might be some balance issues here and there but these are quickly resolved. The idea behind DLC is to give players more varitey, be that with skins or commanders it's down to your personal preference and you are no way forced to buy it to be able to compete.  I can say that although CoH2 does not possess that same unique feeling that vcoh had, it is still a remarkable and incredibly fun game that continues to get better with each passing month. I have personally played over 600 hours on the beta and current version combined and I still find new ways to play and each game is never the same. You have to remember that the orginal CoH series has had 7 years of patching and improvements whereas CoH2 has only been out for less than a year. Therefore I believe it's unfair to judge the sequel so harshly at this stage. Within that time period the developers have added a huge range of content including; Steam Workshop with user created maps and mods, offical developer created maps, new units, commanders, leaderboards, chat rooms and with plenty more on the way.  Notable improvements over the original include: Better Graphics, Bulletins, Variety in choices that makes you stand out from the crowd ie commanders, skins faceplates etc, New Features like Cold Tech and True Sight which add more tactical elements. For instance you must now keep your troops warm during a blizzard by placing them near a fire or in a house otherwise they will freeze to death.  Now on to the game's flaws. Currently I believe the developers are pre-occuiped in bringing out more dlc content then spending the most time balancing the game and improving performance. Fair enough that they have to make money but I'd much rather they focused on tweaking the current game first then adding dlc like theatre of war missions. The variety in commanders is great and all but loads of the abilities have been reused in other commanders which takes away the uniqueness of certain commanders. Theres still quite some work to do before it can be considered a proper ESport as the replay viewer still needs additional features however it is constantly improving. Compared to something like Starcraft 2, CoH2 just doesn't have the player base or the resources unlike blizzard. I honestly think that if relic promoted the game and advertised it properly it would have generated a lot more interested. As it happens the advertising around the launch date was literally non-existent.  Conclusion  Score: 8/10 Current State  Although this game has got a way to go before it can be considered to be a worthy sequel to the first, I believe that over time it will get there and even surpass it's predecessor. Relic has been listening to user feedback and many of the new features are a result of this. So if your either a fan of the old game or looking to try out a proper real time strategy then look no further. I cannot recommend this game enough.

CoH2 is a great WWII themed RTS with a strong focus on combat. Amazingly detailed mechanics and physics, especially the dynamics of taking cover behind world objects and in garrisons, make CoH2 a uniquely realistic gaming experience.

After putting in a lot of hours on the old COH i feel that this game has made some improvements to an already good RTS. i've clocked 370hrs which may look like child's play to some people's hours but i've tried every part of this game and enjoy it to say the least. Other than that i'd say its worth the money the overall unit command works well 10/10 from me

Not realy your classic RTS formula, resources gather automatic no need for harvesting, but they can be increased by capturing points and building resource points. Units can reinforce if close to a reinforcement point, lil like the wh40k unit system. Besides that unit variety: a lot. Even more with custom mods. Campaign ya well, wish there was also a German campaign but overall it's decent. Additional campaign with Ardennes offence wich is also pretty decent.   Game can crash sometimes when loading the after match report but that doesnt happen too often. If you've played CoH1 then this one will not dissapoint, except maybe for the great ammount of dlc for sale (also mods for that lol).   Online players are usualy friendly and most of the time u will have an enjoyable match, of course u will also encounter the few unpleasant exceptions to that. Good thing also: theatre of war, custom missions that can be played solo or coop.   Only downside for me is the loot system wich is pretty much random play for 10 min or play for an hour, win or lose u never know when the loot is going to be coming your way.   Difficulty: easy (real easy) the ai doesnt even move unless you strike first, normal the ai only moves when you capture a point, hard the ai comes for all your base, and fast, expert u need to be faster then the ai with everything because otherwise f*ckin forget about it, u dead. So would say difficulty is well done.  Advice: vanilla (standard) is maybe not the best experience but with some custom skins and tuning packs its well worth it.

I must say, I am a fan of RTS games and this has to be one of my favorites! The game itself is odd in the playstyles that you have to use to win/loose, but overall its fun- especially with friends. I'll quickly list the Pro's and the Con's and move on with life.  Now starting out with the game itself the Singleplayer is something you want to stay away from, since it's disgustingly inaccurate in a sense of historical terms and how the Soviet troops were treated, essentially it's a pile of ♥♥♥♥. ON THE OTHER HAND the multiplayer is pretty nice with the maps and gameplay styles that you'll have to use depending which side and country you are on. The maps are consistantly different which is good in a successful RTS game.    Now back to the gameplay styles and statistics as I stated before its all up to who you are, Axis or Allies. Depending who you are you'll have to take many things into context including the map, which commander you've chosen and who are you allies (If not playing 1v1). Continuing with that communicating is a major thing since if you are trying to do a spear push to middle point and your the only one doing it, that's pretty bad teamwork. Along with saying that the Allies are VERY WEAK if you are in a 2v2 or above match and you do not work together, since if you think about it The Big Three (US, UK, Russia) worked together to push the Germans back and end the war? Well it works the same in here, if you have a US and Soviets and they try to independently take points it can work, but without helping each other in the late game they will truly and utterly get massacred and loose.   Now the technical things, the AI can sometimes be stupid, but it works and isn't as bad compared to many other RTS titles out there. The DLC is really nice and pretty good, but the prices I think are way to high- get them when they are on sale instead of full price. Then within the game are the micro-transaction ♥♥♥♥♥ which but don't leave out, skins, commanders, faceplates, and bundles! Which are all over $5.99 and $5.99 is the cheapest the 'bundles' come in. Also majority of the time within the game it is Axis sided if you don't know what your doing- as in if you make one fatal mistake there goes the game. It's weird.   In total however the game is truly worth the buy, especially if it's on sale! The game is full hours of fun with or without your friend playing in a PVP manner. The DLC's are also worth it if you get tired of playing only Soviets and Wermacht, but the drops you can get after playing a game can spice things up with the abilities that they have to offer. So yes I rate this positive since it is truly a fun WWII RTS Game.   Have fun, and happy hunting!

I really loved COH and I also like COH 2 despite it's weaknesses.  First of all, the game has great graphics and game mechanics. Especially on 4v4 MP matches this games become great on the endgame when you have tank battles like in kursk and you fight for every point as your tickets amount become low. You then face a sometimes little disturbing battles where many soldiers die for holding this point and you realise how hard war can be when a single salve of artillery fire kills 20 of your brave elite soldierts who did everything to follow your order.  The singleplayer is also nice and I really wish they had spent more effort German and allied campaigns.  Pros:  + Great RTS with many options and ways to achieve victory + Cool mechanics and graphics + awesome atmosphere  negs:  - Bugs (they are plenty of them) - Devs. not caring about bugs and prefering to sell more useless skins on 5 GB updates every week - every replay you save will become incompatible with every 'skin update'...... - Not very popular, it sometimes takes ages until you find a MP game to join in  Conclusion:  I love this game despite the bugs and greedy devs not caring at all. It would be nice if a company like blizzard was behind this project, then we would get a gaming experience that reaches levels you never expected but sadly, this will never happen.  What ever, I'd buy again, but not the CE as I spend more than 100 € for it to have to buy every single DLC for like 20 - 30 €... Greed over quality.
It's ok I guess.

For those who have played COH1 and are still on the fence about buying this game, this review is for you:  When I first purchased COH1, it was love at first sight. With 6 compelling campaigns and awesome mods and maps to play with after getting bored with the vanilla version, I got hooked real quick, I probably spent a good 200+ hours playing it off and on for the past 2 years. The campaigns had the same feeling as the first 2 Call of Duties mixed with a hint of Band of Brothers.  Since I loved COH1 so much, I decided to disregard the enormous amount of negative reviews and get it anyways.  COH2 is originally set on the Eastern Front, which suffice to say is better than the Eastern Front mod for COH1 in so many ways. Mainly, I like COH2 more because it comes with a great campaign, and doesn't require you to force restart your OP PC every time you try to boot up a game.  That being said, the campaign storyline in COH2 was a little better than if you compared them side-by-side with any of the COH1 campaigns. It felt a little more cheesy and CoD-ish than Brothers In Arms: EiB, but the same general attitude was used with great effect and had me compelled to play through the entire campaign in one sitting.  Then there are of course the countless DLCs that come with this game. Mainly, most of these are microtransactions, where now instead of doctrines, there are commanders. As for the other, more formal DLCs, there are 3 more factions to choose from if you get them. Also Ardennes Assault brings a new kind of campaign that is extremely different from what you'd normally expect, It's sort of a Turn-Based strategy on top of the base game that plays differently each campaign, with 'special events' where you can unlock certain vehicles for certain companies throughout the game. And then there's also mission packs, which can provide you with maybe 30 more hours of fun.   So all in all, would I recommend this game? I personally would, but only if there is a really good sale on it. The microtransactions kind of turned me off, but it wasn't gamebreaking for me. The campaign is good too, and for some it can make you walk away from it questioning your own moral integrity. Hope this helped!

Company of Heroes 2 Review:

EXPLAINING MYSELF Before I start my review,I will say that I played the first Company of Heroes with all its expansion packs(Opposing Fronts and Tales of Valor) and that I had a rather enjoyable experience.The factions were diverse and unique and the campaign had some challenge in it.The multiplayer was the epitome of multiplayer strategy.  ONE OF THESE THINGS IS NOT LIKE THE OTHER So,what does Company of Heroes 2 offer that its predecessor doesn't?Well,the setting is different.Eastern front in the center of the game,therefore Ostheer(East German army) and the Soviet Red Army are the available factions to play as.The Germans have smaller squads but are generally superior in equipment and training(e.g.the Panzergrenadiers can be upgraded with Panzershreck to eliminate armor,none of the Soviet infantry has any upgrade to do so).The Soviets have larger squads,which gives them better chances to survive and reinforce(except the Engineers who have 4 and Sniper team who has 2,the rest of the Soviet squads have 6 men).  NICE,BUT HOW DO YOU PLAY IT? The gameplay is the same as in the last game;capture point to get resorces and don't let the territories get cut off from your main base.However,instead of some points offering munitions,fuel or manpower, most points offer both munitions and fuel(in a smaller amount) with some offering just fuel or munitions but in a higher amount.Those that offer both may be secured to either increase their munitions or fuel output(but not both).Tactics such as taking cover,flanking,suppressing and vehicle positioning are important to win battles,since a heavy tank can be defeated if engaged with a AT gun while the bazooka team flanks and attacks his weak back armor.Overall,it's the same game,but...  LET IT SNOW The snow ain't just for aesthetic purposes.Heavy snow can slow down both infantry and vehicles,and in some situations your men will freeze to death if they are not in a building,vehicle or near a fireplace.Blizzarrds may occur at random(you will get a warning and a timer telling you how much is left before it hits).It lowers the sight range of all your units,while freezing the men,forcing you to take care of them.Vehicles and men leave marks on the snow so you know if someone passed there and where he went.  YURI,WHAT DO YOUR BLUE EYES SEE? Tue line of sight is implemented in this game.In simple terms,your units cannot see behind walls or through trees,making ambushes a potent tactical solution(the first game didn't have true line of sight).It is a very fun mechanic that I haven't seen since the games of Stormregion(Codename:Panzers and Rush for Berlin).It makes scouting a neccessary maneuver to your strategy and smoke screens a life saver from artillery and machineguns(my Soviet Shock troops saved a lot of my men with their smoke grenades).An excellent addition to the game.LOVE IT!  WANT TO GO TO A THEATER? Theater of War is and addition to the singleplayer portion of the game.You have solo challenges and coop scenarios.These can vary from officer assasination,holding a position,eliminating a armoured column during the blizzard and so on.It extends the life of the game and if you have a friend,some of the scenarios you can play with him.  COMPANY OF FUN The multiplayer is so fun I don't know what words to use.It's immersive and action packed,but smart action.You need to make decisions fast and smart to win.The user interface really helps here;on the bottor right you can select the production buildings,set a rally point and order a unit to arrive.this is important in the early stages of the game,when deployment to the frontline is crucial.The various maps also help in this,considering that they are different in sizer and terrain.  SINGLE IS COLD I played the first three missions of the campaign and didn't continue because I ran out of time(I played this during the free weekend action).The campaign is inferior to that from CoH1.Whil CoH1 displayed the Americans,British and Germans as normal people doing their duty,the Soviet army men are portrayed as cowards who shoot their own men in the back.True,attrocities were made by the Red Army and the methods they used were brutal,but htere must have been some heroic moments.Sadly,the campaign doesn't show that,and the way the story is presented doesn't help.It is told via a flashback,which makes it feel detached from reality.Add in that the focus is on the bad side of the Red Army(and that the Germans are nothing more than obstacle,rather that a force),while showing nothing bad about the German army(they did attrocities,no army is safe from that) adn you get and rather empty and almost surreal story that is hard to believe or take serious.  COMRADE,WHAT IS THE CONCLUSION? Company of Heroes 2 is an excellent strategy with excellent multiplayed balancing,a sizeable singleplayer content and a dull campaign story.If you're buying it for the multiplayer,you won't be dissapointed.If you're buying it for the challenges,missions and scenarios in th Theater of War you will get a kick from it.If you're buying it for and interesting story then you will get dissapointed with it.

Holy ♥♥♥♥, the DLCs! The business model for this game is atrocious! HOWEVER, it would be unfair to rate it poorly for that. I spite of my bias, I will not descriminate against a game like this. There is so many games out there that has a ♥♥♥♥ load of DLC, like Killing Floor or Borderlands 2! However, like those mentioned games, this doesn't feel incomplete. It doesn't feel like any important parts were cut out and held for ransom. The game, stand alone, without DLC, is excellent.    I didn't spend a dime on DLC, never will. I enjoy the game as is, it's fun. The gameplay style is unique from what I'm used to, coming from Command and Conquer series at the time. Instead of rushing your enemy or rushing for flanks, you're really rushing for choke points and trying to hold them. I suck at this game.  I do have some complaints though. Why is there no sell unit option? Why not give units the ability to flee the battle when at HQ for exchange of a little refund and your unit cap being replinished? It always feels weird sending units to their deaths in order to build something better. Also, an update did the saddest thing ever for me! They implemented build limits on IS2 tanks! Why? I Know the spam was real, I admit it was op... but why not punish me for it instead of simply banning me from doing it? What if you increased the costs for every additional unit, or build time, something!   regardless, it is an excellent game, especially with friends. DLC isn't worth it though, save your ♥♥♥♥ing money.

I remember being sad and angry with the choices Relic made when playing the beta of this game while still being very much a fanboy of the original. Bought the game after it matured a bit and saw it for what it really was. An, allthough not exactly the same, experince akin to the original COH. An RTS with focus on smaller engagements and zero to none focus on basebuilding. Good grahpics, physics and a steep but very satisfying learning curve.  Good game for just wanting to build giant tanks and artillery and utterly destroy the enemy in a compstomp or to really get your tactical/strategic itch scratched in very tense and stressfull 1 on 1 matches in automatch. Downside of the game is the multiple DLC. The new factions offer more than enough of new contact, however each faction has extra commanders as well which in theory you can get by playing the game for free... this will take some luck and a lot of time. If you want to play a specific commander, be prepared to spend some extra cash or invest a lot of time.  It took some time, but this has become a game not onyl worthy of the name 'company of heroes' but has also added on to that legacy.

Within the genre of RTS WWII games, COH2 is viewed by some as merely a sequel to vCOH. Though it is similar by virture of genre and setting; It's not merely a sequel! It's a whole new interactive gameplay--from units to maps to missions. The basic game commanders as totally adequate for adding a lot of variety (which vCOH had only 3 choices) via the commanders. Buying the DLC just enhances the options though in few cases adds newer units or abilities. Personally, I like this--buy it if you want it approach.   COH2 deliveres a lot a fun, tense gameplay. Truesight, weather tech, and new infantry pathing abilities, along with a dynamically changing battlefield, really creates some great gaming. (Oh, vehicle pathing is still somewhat spastic.)   The asymetrical balance is somewhat daunting to learn (much like the Brits once nerfed), with the Wehrmacht being most similar to vCOH. Here the game made some subtle differences that makes the Wehrmacht somewhat easier to manage (without micro-managing). The Soviets, however, are fun but exasperating to play (to some degree like the Americans in vCOH). Soviet teching is not at all linear or even possible in many matches, given the massive bleeding inflicted by losses. Yet, once you've learned what combination of Soviet arms to cobble together, the Soviets really give the Wehrmacht a run for their money. Ultimately, a Soviet player has to be far more descriminating and anticipatory in what units to produce than the Wehrmact, since an early Panzer or Ostwind can ruin an otherwise good game. Likewise, the stronger Wehrmacht tanks can't afford to get ahead of infantry support. Hence, Soviets arms typically dominate the Wehrmacht infantry, whereas the Wehrmacht tanks can outlast most Soviet armor. It's a truly asymetrical theater.  COH2 is a great game. Sequel-like but not a sequel. It's got numerous improvements (and differences....even when vCOH had some better aspects) that make COH, well, a bit old.   Cost of the buy-in is definitely higher; but the fun factor (for me) is worth it! Bigger than that, is the hardware requirements to run this graphic hog. But if you've got the gaming system that can run it, I'd recommend that you try it. It's not a FPS, but it's an awesome RTS.

I would highly recommend this game to any RTS fans. Unlike older RTS games, the Company of Heroes series puts emphasis on combined arms tactics and keeping your troops alive vice the old 'build a bunch of stuff and throw it in a meat grinder' method of 90s games. Cover grants troops defensive bonuses and can mean the difference of winning or losing small skirmishes.  There are a some changes from the original COH in that there are less chokepoint-like maps and more open terrain. However, the map editor that is bundled with the game is seeing a lot of the original maps ported over. Some fans of the original are also unhappy with the DLC that is being release, but the majority of it is cosmetic - vehicle skins, decorative name plates. The commanders can change things up as no single commander has access to all perks. However, Relic appears to be tweaking balance as time goes on to prevent overpowered units and tactics.

Where to start? Company of Heroes is one of my favorite RTS series of all time. And CoH 2 is a great addition to the series, with a few exceptions. But i'll start with what I love about this game. It's a refreshing change from CoH, switching focus from the United States forces, to the Red Army. It's a nice switch from the traditional WWII soldier, to Russian conscripts. We have a nice change in vehicles and unit upgrades, as well as units. Not to mention, fighting against the notorious harsh weather elements of Russia is also very immersive. There's nothing like trying to prevent your men from getting hypothermia during a blizzard while fending off Wehrmacht panzers spitting fire and platoons of storm troopers, machine gunners backed by mortar crews! Aside from all this, there is a pretty darastic change in the CoH we know and love. The dreadful 'microtransaction' has made a needless appearence in this excellent game. Now, if you're one of those saps who love paying 1-3 USD for cool skins and such, search no more. But regardless, those in-game purchasable items are, in my opinion, completely dumb and useless. The other new feature I strongly dislike is the fact you need to unlock Generals and customize them. There are lots of 'em, and if you're new to the series, it could be a bit overwhelming at first. You can now pick your generals and select from a VERY large variety of unit 'perks' if you will. All of these 'perks' are ranked such as common, rare, legendary, etc. And they pretty much add a bonus to a specific unit. Dumb, but it doesn't ruin the gameplay. And that's why I can comfortably recommend this game to someone else.

Company of Heroes 2 plays like a well-polished, stand-alone, overpriced expansion pack to the original Company of Heroes 2. It introduces the Soviets as a new playable faction, comes with a shiny campaign, new maps, and a few new mechanics. Aside from that and the enhanced visuals it's just about the exact same game. Even the in-game interface is damn near identical.  It makes for a game that plays well and fans are certain to enjoy, but simultaneously isn't very appealing to non-hardcore fans. CoH2 does bring some improvements, like an ongoing player advancement system that unlocks statistical upgrades and aesthetic enhancements for multiplayer. Theatre of War is another great addition that adds tons of story-driven co-op vs ai, solo botmatches, and solo challenge missions.  The rest of the new mechanics are mostly fluff. Ice, snow, and cold weather are notable new game mechanics, but it never feels like they have a major impact on the way the game is played. You can blow up ice beneath units to sink them, you can track units through snow, and units can die from cold. It sounds impactful, it should be in theory, but in practice it doesn't really change the way you play the game all too much. This is further worsened by the fact that most of the campaign - and multiplayer/ToW maps - doesn't involve ice, snow, or cold weather at all.  The singleplayer campaign is simultaneously better and worse than CoH's. Its structure is similar to the original CoH, not Tales of Valor, but its missions aren't quite as obnoxiously long-winded: they're just long-winded now. There also seems to be a bit more variation in objectives and limitations during missions. Yet the game is riddled with grossly exaggerated parodies of things-that-ocassionally-happened in the Soviet army during WW2, which eventually ruin the experience even for westerners.  Company of Heroes 2's multiplayer is very much like the original CoH. It still works well. There's not much to talk about here other than said ongoing progression system that allows you to build up a custom loadout of enhancements and commanders. That makes for a bit more variation, but the enhancements are mostly minor.  Visually Company of Heroes 2 is a notable improvement over the original game, but not as much over Dawn of War 2. The benchmark seems simultaneously uglier and underperforming versus playing a regular match, but that's likely a matter of perspective. Textures are still a sore point even with everything cranked to Maximum. Most importantly, Company of Heroes 2 is easily one the more demanding games out right now and it certainly doesn't look the part.  The major DLC packs are Theatre of War campaigns. Those include botmatches / co-op vs ai / solo challenges in a campaign-like narrative structure. That's actually a substantial amount of content for the price if you like CoH's singleplayer gameplay.   Conclusion / TLDR  Company of Heroes 2 is a solid entry in the Company of Heroes series that's sure to please fans. But it's not a substantial improvement over Company of Heroes in any regard. Recommended for fans of the franchise. Anyone else might want to look twice or wait for a sale. COMPANY OF HEROES 2 is an adrenaline heart pumping strategic thinking triggering work of gaming art. The last time I saw this level of strategic depth and detail to realism was when playing table top war games like NAPOLEON AT WATERLOO. Here the computer takes the number crunching out of the players hands while delivering tons of statistical info on screen as things like weather and terrain play huge roles in the outcome of battles.  Weather such as snow can effect armies by freezing them to death and slowing them down. And having one type of snow variable effecting different things wasn't enough for RELIC they also had to add in blizzards which effect line of sight while magnifying the consequences of regular snowfall. By building fire pits or entering buildings units are able to stay warm and be protected by the demoralizing elements of nature. Snow banks can be blasted away to clear a path and make traveling easier.  I found myself getting attached to ground troops as they would survive battles and become experienced veterans only to feel my heart sink a bit as a veteran infantry tank killing unit got decimated by a almost dead King Tiger tank. Then there were those times when only one soldier was left squeezing off that final rocket which lands a lucky shot making a armor unit into a slag of burning metal.  Pretty much every unit in COMPANY OF HEREOS 2 can be upgraded with better weapons and defensive measures like smoke screens to better survive the brutal battlefield.  Graphics are stunning looking like something out of a table top miniatures war game with detail one can zoom into seeing the wood grain on rifles and the whites of the enemies eyes.  Sound effects are unequaled in their immersive power putting me in a different world consumed by unrelenting remorseless war where the only choice is to fight or die. It was a electric mind jolt of terror hearing soldiers screaming in agony as their bunker was drenched with cascading waves of flamethrower fire. Where's the Thorazine!? I think am having a flashback!  COMPANY OF HEROES 2 a nonstop battle fest of screaming metal and unbound heroism by valiant Russian men and women fighting for what they believe in. Buy it! Play it! Experience the horror and the glory that is COMPANY OF HEROES 2!!!

I sincerely feel like this game could be the best RTS of all time. I love the historical accuracy with all of the units and how they work, and I really like the destructible environments and epic battles.   This game has some really glaring weaknesses though that keep it from being the masterpiece that it truly could be:  1. 75% or more of the players online play as axis only, and the reason why is that the Axis are OP, mainly because of their   amazingly strong super heavy tiger and king tiger tanks. If Relic nerfed the axis, or, better yet, got rid of their OP super heavy tanks, the game would be much better. Needless to say I mostly play as Russians and the USF, and to add to balance problems, the USF still aren't as strong as they should be.   2. Horrible matchmaking. It took me 10 minutes to find a game, and when I did it was with a level 95 player... and I'm level 40. I suppose part of this is because of the relatively small player base, but still, they could use some work.  3. For DLC I love the idea of skins, but why limit it to tanks? If Relic made new infantry skins, they'd make more money. However, I'm completely against the DLC commander idea. Why? Because in many ways its pay to win. 'Oh but you can unlock them ingame'. Rare commanders tend to be the best, and I've only unlocked 1 the whole time I've played. People who spend money on the game tend to do better because of the DLC commanders.   So overall, I love the game, but I have some key issues with it that I just mentioned. This game has the potential to be a masterpiece, but some really stupid things have reduced its awesomeness. I sincerely hope that Relic fixes all the issues with the game, and with their plans for the future like adding new factions and campaigns, I look forward to what will come: PLZ PLZ PLZ add Italians and Brits!  Overall: 8/10

I used to play a lot of Warcraft 3 and Age Of Empires 3 when growing up, and have recently gotten back into competitive RTS games with COH2 being the first I've spent more then 100 hours on. I intend to keep playing right now, as I think this game has a whole lot of potential and continues to go on great sales (50%-75% off is totally worth it for the base game + Western Front Armies).   Like Relic's other games, in COH2 you build squads of soldiers and single vehicle units from your base, and fight against the opposing player on a rich, destructable map. Skirmish games are Victory-Point based, meaning you try to hold certain points to reduce your opponent's score over time; as long as you are holding 2 out of the 3 victory points, you will be causing their score to go down. When it reaches 0, you lose.  You don't gather resources, instead resources trickle in based on your current army size / population, and the sectors on the map you have captured. The main resource is manpower, which is used for purchasing every unit and upgrade, and you receive more for, the smaller your army is. The second most important resource is fuel, which allows you to build vehicles and research upgrades, and finally there is munitions, which allows your units to use their abilities, such as throwing grenades, placing mines, and getting better guns. Fuel and Munitions are received based on capturing and holding more points on the map.  PROS - Very fun multiplayer battles. COH2 is much like a game of chess, where there are hard counters, soft counters, and many elements to the battlefield. Although base-building is not a major aspect of the game by any means (and that is something I usually love in my RTS's), there is enough going on to keep a player thinking the whole time. - Blowing up buildings! Placing Mines! Artillery Barrages! Tank battles! Machine Guns and Mortar Support Teams! FLAMETHROWERS! Units are fun to use. Nearly every unit has at least one upgrade or ability, so even though you may have less than 20 units on the map, there is a lot to do with them - set up the MG in the right place, sprint your sniper to better cover, have your mortar throw down smoke bombs for a flanking assault by your shock troops, or perform a risky ramming maneuver with your T34 tank. - Randomness (known as RNG) gives an exciting element to the battle. COH2 is still figuring out the right amount of it, but it makes responding to what happens in a battle as important as making good plans. Sometimes, your AT gun misses three shots in a row, allowing your opponent's tank to blitz through your lines. Other times, you hit those three times, penetrate one, and knock the tank's engine out, leaving it dead in the water. Will he risk his engineers trying to repair it, or will you manage to clear the crew, leaving the tank abandoned, and take it for yourself? #adapt  CONS - Three main multiplayer systems could be better, in my opinion: Commander, warspoils, & ELO ranking. :::::Commander system is regarded by the community to be inferior to COH1's, where you would pick a commander and then be able to spend your command points on . In COH2, you are allowed to take 3 Commanders into the game, and pick one during the game, which will give you a single 'Roster' of 5 Units and Abilities. Different Commanders for each faction are mostly different mixes of the same pool of about 12 units and abilities, some combinations of which are regarded as clearly stronger than others right now. (12/27/2014) :::::Warspoils is the reward for playing multiplayer. 1 Commander, 'Intel Bulletin' (in-game stat upgrade, i.e. +3% Rate of Fire to your machine Guns) or Vehicle skin is randomly rewarded for about every 3 hours of playing the game in multiplayer. You have no control over what you will get, duplicates are common, and there is no way to trade/craft these. It seems the developers are actively looking for feedback to improve this system, and I hope to see it changed in the future. :::::ELO Ranking for automatch is not transparent. Without third party tools, you are unaware of your rank, and you are unaware of your opponent's relative skill level. I feel this should be made more transparent. - Singleplayer story is a little lackluster, being what got this game in trouble in Europe upon launch. Much of the story focuses on war crimes committed by the Russian Red Army. If this does not bother you, the missions are varied and interesting. - Community needs to improve. Ranked Automatch with random players is a staple in modern RTS games. The intense tactical nature of this game means that you will lose some engagements in a skirmish; this is OK. Unit preservation and coordinating with your allies is very much a key element to winning, but often it is hard to work with strangers over the internet.

The CoH series is by far one of the most underrated RTS game franchises ever made, and my favorite by far. And unlike cheap, polished, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ FPS titles like COD that turn the meaning of realism into a pure ♥♥♥♥-like facade (and come up with virtually nothing innovative whatsoever in terms of gameplay; YOU WANNA FIGHT ABOUT IT) both games in the Company of Heroes franchise are in many ways works of RTS innovative genius. I suppose I shouldn't be juxtaposing war franchises of two almost entirely different genres, but Call of Duty, for all of its overly-generic and high budget corporate we-don't-give-a-♥♥♥♥-about-what-you-think-because-we-make-money-off-of-this philosophy, is literally nothing compared to games like CoH2, where an extensive amount of time (and effort) on a comparatively smaller budget produced a game that is just impossible not to appreciate if you enjoy ultra-realistic RTS games. And I mean ultra-realistic in the sense that some of even the finest and most minute IRL factors that affect tactical maneuvering, technology gaps, terrain, cover, and even mixed-unit and combined arms doctrines, are taken into account and make an enormous difference in any battle's outcome.   The AI still tends to often be unbalanced, as it was in CoH1--it's typically either too easy to defeat or virtually impossible not to get tactically crushed by--but in CoH2 in particular a greater amount of emphasis has been placed on player-to-player cooperation and player-versus-player, rather than AI, action, and this game comes with an unprecedented ♥♥♥♥♥on of new multiplayer campaigns and game modes. Another vast improvement CoH2 has over its predecessor is a vastly less glitchy, and also even more realistic physics engine: possibly every law of physics governing the difference between two different types of tanks going head to head and trying to destroy one another is taken into account, and only games like World of Tanks go into greater detail over the physics of compartmentalized and regional damage than CoH2 does. But where WoT focuses exclusively, of course, on the physics governing its namesakes interacting in various environments, CoH2 more or less runs an entire carbon copy of the IRL universe within its own engine, leaving hardly any stones unturned, and it makes a clearly visible and tactical difference in gameplay. The literal only things I can think of that happen in the real world that don't also happen in CoH2 are vehicle motors freezing over in deep winter, and the ever-present problem that all factions frequently faced throughout the Second World War involving tank guns occasionally jamming or misfiring and HMG barrels overheating and becoming unusable.   Best part is that CoH2 is constantly being developed and having new features, units, and doctrines added to it almost on a monthly basis, derived overwhelmingly from community feedback. Games by other developers such as Valve also *sometimes* do this, but Relic really far outpaces them and most other developers in both the quality and the pace of their own involvement in improving and adding features in all areas of the game. When people experiment with new units, doctrines, maps, and other aspects of gameplay and present them to Relic, if they're good enough they pretty much always make it into the official game in some form. Contrast this with Valve, whose master plan for improving their gaming communities these days exclusively involves making their fanbases ♥♥♥♥ waterfalls of money for them in return for stupid hats.   Relic barely survived THQ's falling off the face of the earth last year, but even with what little they had left to work with in the end they managed to produce something that is really, really ♥♥♥♥ing impressive in my eyes.  TL;DR 9.8/10, this game kicks the ♥♥♥ of every FPS and nearly every RTS you have ever played, and in virtually no way falls short of what Relic intended it to be.

As a former CoH 1 veteran and fan of competitive multiplayer strategy games, I finally found the game that will fill both aforementioned roles.   When CoH 2 was out, I refused to buy it after being frustrated by the inglorious end of CoH 1. Veterans of CoH 1 will understand... abandonment, bugs, imbalance, NAT connection issues, too many exploits and lame stuff that would ruin your fun in the long run.  I grabbed it on sale 2 weeks back together with Western Front Armies and I can say 'well spent money'.  For quite some time, I have been on the look out for a modern era strategy game that has deep tactical gameplay combined with an excellent multiplayer service; the one that you can just click automatch and start playing (ranked or not) against someone of equal skill. Something that games like 'League of Legend' do very succesfully. And it gets better, as with the newly launched observer mode, you can now watch games live from other players.   As for the game itself, it exceeded my expectations. Graphics, voice overs, mechanics, the vaulting feature, the cold and much more are of superb quality. So much improvement over CoH 1 that I can sit here for hours listing every single one of them.   As for the balance I have yet to see any. From previous threads, I can see there were some issues but from what I have seen so far, most of them have been fixed. I believe you can expect to find a well balanced multiplayer experience.  -To CoH Veterans: Do not be as reluctant as me, BUY IT. It is not the pain we all remember as seen in CoH 1. It actually exceeds expectations. Hopefully, you will be as surprised (in a good way) as I am with it.  -To newcomers: I definitely recommend it. However, don't expect to find a game that plays like age of empires, starcraft etc. Remember it is a TACTICAL strategy game. A lot of stuff need to be done to achieve victory apart from training soldiers&tanks and blobbing them all in a single attack. My recommendation: Watch replays and live games! preferably from top players. This is the method I used to become better at this game. Watching how other players go around the battlefield can be an invaluable lesson that will only make you better. If you cant be bothered watching it all, just use 2X, 4X + speeds. You can still learn stuff even on Fast Forward.   The only negative that I want to mention is the great number of trolls and whiners that are present within the community. Unfortunately, that is something that wasn't adressed properly from CoH 1. If you take a look in the forums, you will see people whining, screaming over balance, trolling etc etc.   I believe there will always be small or big issues with balance with games like CoH2 due to the nature of the game itself. However, crying, cursing and screaming like a spoilt 10 year old 'OMG OMG OP THIS OP THAT NERF THIS BUFF THAT ♥♥♥♥ NOOB, WTF RELIC, STFU OMG OMG', even if you have a legit point, it does not make it any better.   As with the first CoH, there were REAL issues with balance. Indeed! however, this was the excuse for people to start whining about everything. even for things that weren't broken. From my experience, most of the whining comes from L2P (Learn to play) issues. People that expect this game to be like age of empires. Sorry guys, this is NOT AoE. Learn to play well first then cry about balance. You will see that the things you call OP, UP or Broken are actually lack of experience and skill. Both Experience and Skill comes from playing and LEARNING from your mistakes.   Thats all!  9/10 Keep at the good work guys ;)

In many ways this game is great but unfortunately it has been poorly managed.   Balance is based on what on whats popular and whats selling. This is also the case with the various commanders/doctrines that give you access to different units and strategies. These are currently being sold at $5 each. One egregious example of an imbalanced commander/doctrine is the one that allows for the deployment of a King Tiger. This tank (best in game) only costs manpower to deploy and all of the other tanks in the game cost fuel.   The community managers and balancing teams have very little involvement the community. There is practically no interaction with them on the forums and most emails sent Relics way (about hacking, glitches, balancing) are ignored. Infamous hackers on Coh1 and Coh2 have been left unbanned for years despite mountains of complaints, videos and emails to Relic. The game previous community manager was hated by the community for being obsessed with 'triggering' content and censoring the chat to create a family fiendly game. The units in the game regularily say swears that are censored in the games chat and forum.  Overall you'll find that about half your games are very enjoyable and mostly balanced experiences.

Perhaps the first point of reference for reviewing COH2 should be its predecessor, Company of Heroes. In many ways, people who played the original will find many aspects of COH2 familiar (the cover system, many game mechanics and a few units). That being said, the sequel does also include a fair amount of impressive new content (interactive scenery, dynamic line of sight, and increased unit abilities). Considering these issues, I would strongly advise buying this game.   The only fly in the ointment is the balancing issues. Anybody who has played COH2 would have to acknowledge that there seems to be a strong Axis bias (which is reflected in the people searching for a game as those factions; 80:20 Axis to Allied ratios are not uncommon). I freely admit that on paper, the Allies have many good units, but in my opinion their reliance on micro-management makes them far less attractive than their relatively a-move-ish Axis equivalents.  In short, there is still room for improvement such as tinkering with the balancing, and new unit abilities (sniping drivers out of light vehicles, etc) and in-game voice chat, but overall I would say that this is a game that, with the right attitude, will keep you entertained for years.  8/10

Company of heroes two is the sequel to the 2006 game 'Company of heroes.' This game is based on the Eastern front during WW2 and at the time of writing this review they have recently added the western front DLC allowing for a multi front WW2 RTS game. Although this game isn't on-par with its predecessor, it is an exciting and fun RTS game.   The campaign on this game has a decent story line and well thought out battles with tactical decisions the player must make in order to win.  The multiplayer is fun, fast and repetitive. There are hundreds of players online for most of the day making it easy to get into games. There are many different tactics that can be used e.g: Flanking, ambushes, counters, ect and as for strategy there are doctrines that contain special ability's and units to suit different players play styles. The map is mostly destructible and can change drastically during play making early, mid and finally late game different experiences all together. Team work is encouraged and coordinated attacks and defences go a long way in winning a game. There is some customizability of your army through vehicle skins and different commanders.   Overall I would rate this game a 8/10 and is definitely worth your money and time if you like RTS.  Any thoughts expressed in this review are my own personal opinion. I hope you find this useful.

Pinning a Soviet rifle section with MG42 fire is extremely satisfying. Stunning and knocking out a Bolshevik tanks with carefully concealed, ambushing PaK's is amazeballs. There is a great sense of Teutonic satisfaction in pinning enemy infantry with MG fire, hitting them with mortars, while flanking with rifle sections to annihlate them. This is not an easy game to jump into and dominate if you are not experienced with RTS games, but it is much more thoughtful than games like Starcraft.

Disclaimer: This is being written by a terrible, terrible RTS player who really needs to lrn2play and gitgud. I only play multiplayer, never touched the campaign. (Recipe for disaster and scrubbyness, I know)  I had a thing for warhammer and real world war history, and so I bought this game as part of the big relic package that included CoH1, Space Marine, and all of DoW1 and DoW2. Progression is similar to Warcraft/Starcraft and other standard RTS titles - basebuild, pile resources, microharass early game and build defenses while preparing for a big push lategame. The differences are that it supports a more aggressive style since (like in Dawn of War) you need to expand and claim territory to increase resource flow, and that there is MUCH less researching improvements with teching being integrated into basebuilding (you build infantry tent to unlock infantry tent#2 which unlocks the tank factory)   Personally I like this system better, because it adds more ways to progress beyond 'esports sequence or bust' (as seen in competitive Starcraft). The results are below.  You NEED combined arms and micro to be successful past the very early game. Throwing out a tidal wave of T-34's and conscripts mindlessly will get you lots of bodies and wrecks with little result and a massive resource drain, if the enemy is halfway competent. (Which is how I came to the conclusion stated in the disclaimer) But once you have that, you can pull your weight, and perhaps even carry scrubs like me to victory.   You NEED to be a fast clicker. Speed is everything. If the enemy sends tanks before you have AT defenses, you're done. If you get your guys into key positions and manage to send them support before the enemy starts trying to dislodge them, they'll never leave. And there is no 'esports sequence' because every progression style has a drawback and counter (fast expansion = lots of territory to keep track of, and so on and so forth)   T-34/10 am still trying to learn it (and I HAVE NO OPINION ON GAME BALANCE because it's a can of worms I don't want to think about) but I believe Relic made an amazing new style of RTS.

It's a shame that this game only gets 'Mostly Positive' and even recently 'Mixed' reviews.  I played a fair bit of the original Company of Heroes, and moved over to the second during the early beta. At the time it felt like an incredibly different game, and part of me rejected it outright. However, since playing it for longer I really feel like nothing drastic has changed and the output has been a very fun and engaging RTS.   The gameplay itself is excellent. Unlike some other RTS games like C&C the gameplay is focused much more on micro-play; the way you position your units can win or lose you a game. That's fine, because that's what the majority of the game is focused on. You could have the greatest timings for building up your economy and 'teching' up; but if you leave your big ♥♥♥ tank with its ♥♥♥♥ hanging out then a couple of AT guns, which aren't all that expensive and quickly available, will leave you wish a massive hole in your army. Cover differentiates between negative, none, medium and heavy. The better the cover, the less damage your unit takes. This made everything feel a little bit more focused on the engagements you had, which were happening almost constantly across the map. Despite this, the game's pace feels very relaxed in comparison to other RTS games like Starcraft. You will feel overwhelmed at first but once you get a build order sorted (many are available online) you can forget about the whole macro strategy and focus more on getting your micromanagement up to speed.   There's a good variety of maps, each of which have their own unique personalities and promote, to a minimal degree, a different approach of play. Some buildings are very open field whereas others are heavily laden with buildings you can jump in and out of. So in an open field map you may want to consider how you're going to advance on the enemy; smoke grenades, mortar fire, artillery, a tank line? You have to think on your feet a lot; so when things go well you are very satisfied.   There is a learning curve, you need to have a quick google and glance at places like  coh2.org  or other wikis that explain the different capabilities of units. This is all part of learning a competitive game, and if you like the WW2 theme and the looks of the gameplay then it's well worth the invested time.   A lot of the negative reviews stem from issues of 'balance'. I think these are entirely nonsense. The balance in Company of Heroes 2 is entirely reasonable with no clear steam-rolling from any one faction. Once the British were released people ♥♥♥♥ themselves into thinking they were overpowered because they had no idea how to play. Shortly after, however, players figured out that the Wehrmacht faction's lone sniper unit (an early available unit) could almost negate the British player early on. Everything since has been patched. There will be strategies you find hard to deal with, or some that seem overpowered. However, that is entirely due to the fact that commanders can be used in ways others haven't thought of (even the devs, they're only human) and so rely on the community reporting these worries.   To give an example: Last night I was thrown a curve ball in a 2v2 match where the enemy built nothing but engineers. They attempted to quickly capture the map against the slow-moving British units and rushed for light tanks and vehicles which the British take a little longer to get going. Honestly, I know a lot of players who would have said '♥♥♥♥ it! These Germans are so OP!'. But after capturing their territory that connects the others together (and so denies them resources) we quickly caught back up and gave them a run for their money. It was a fairly normal game (around 30 minutes) because as shocking and powerful their strategy appeared they usually have a hole to exploit which was their lack of focus on anti-tank by trying to get the early-game victory.   Don't let the balance/RNG posts fool you! Relic fairly frequently come off feedback from the community and alter balance; something it works, sometimes not - it was no different in CoH1 as notalgic reviewers like to claim. The game is fantastic and a gem. It's a shame that people protested enough to get rid of some exciting features. There used to be a blizzard mechanic that caused the maps to become bitter cold and lack visibility. Getting units to heat was a must, it slowed down the game pace but I felt it offered a unique style of play where you were rewarded for managing to be mobile during this period or using your time wisely to recoup. You could always veto these maps anyway!   All in all. Good game, give it a whirl, ignore bitter players.

A solid successor the one of my favorite RTS games of all time. Developers are constantly fixing and tweaking the game, ever improving it. WWII setting is interesting, but this is not the only game that has it. (Think of Men of War: Assault Squad) Resource collection is passive, meaning that there are no collection units, you just take territory and resources are given to you based on what area you took. Wide variety of units which all serve different purposes to differing degrees of success. Plenty of maps, both community-made and developer-made, which adds to replayability. Many of the commanders are bit mundane, especially the ones which are given to you for free. Some of the best units in the game, (Tiger Ace, Sturmtiger, etc...) are only available to commanders which need to be purchased, so there is a bit of a discrepancy between players who haven't purchased any commanders, and those who have. Additionally, commanders in the store are a little pricy for my taste, ranging from $2 to $4, but they do add a bit of flavor to any player's loadout. Matchmaking is good, but the low amount of players means that you may very well be matched with players from other continents. (I live in the United States and I often see players from Europe and Asia) Overall, a really good game to buy with some friends if it's on sale, or if you're itching for some historical RTS action.

I can't think of anything to comment, so here's a cinnamon roll recipe:   Ingredients  For the Dough: 1 cup whole milk one 1/4-ounce packet active dry yeast (2 1/2 teaspoons) 1/4 cup plus 1/4 teaspoon granulated sugar 4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted, plus more for the bowl 1 large egg yolk 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract 2 3/4 cups all-purpose flour, plus more if needed 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg For the Filling: All-purpose flour, for dusting 12 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened, plus more for the pan 1/2 cup granulated sugar 3 tablespoons ground cinnamon For the Glaze: 2 cups confectioners' sugar 1/3 cup heavy cream 4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted  Directions  Make the dough: Warm the milk in a medium saucepan over low heat until it reaches about 100. Remove from the heat and sprinkle in the yeast and 1/4 teaspoon sugar (don't stir). Set aside until foamy, 5 minutes. Whisk in the melted butter, egg yolk and vanilla.  Whisk the flour, the remaining 1/4 cup sugar, the salt and nutmeg in the bowl of a stand mixer. Make a well in the center and pour in the yeast mixture. Mix on low speed with the dough hook until thick and slightly sticky. Knead on medium speed until the dough gathers around the hook, 6 minutes. (Add up to 2 more tablespoons flour if necessary.)  Remove the dough and shape into a ball. Butter the mixer bowl and return the dough to the bowl, turning to coat with butter. Cover with plastic wrap and let rise until doubled, 1 hour 15 minutes.  Roll out the dough, fill and cut into buns (see instructions below). Butter a 9-by-13-inch baking pan; place the buns cut-side down in the pan, leaving space between each. Cover with plastic wrap and let rise until doubled, 40 minutes. Preheat the oven to 325.  Bake the buns until golden brown, about 35 minutes. Cool in the pan 15 minutes. Meanwhile, make the glaze: Sift the confectioners' sugar into a bowl, then whisk in the cream and melted butter. Transfer the buns to a rack and spoon the glaze on top while still warm.  How to Form Cinnamon Buns  1. On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a 12-by-14-inch rectangle with the longer side facing you.  2. Spread with the softened butter, leaving a 1/2-inch border on the far long edge. Mix the sugar and cinnamon; sprinkle over the butter.  3. Brush the unbuttered far edge with water. Roll the dough away from you into a tight cylinder and press on the long edge to seal.  4. Cut the cylinder with a sharp knife to make 6 equal-size buns.

So, I would like to be clear, this is a hesitant recommendation. The base game is good. Good enough to be worth buying, even. However, since the release of the game, there's been a trend that I've found entirely unpleasant and unsettling. I'll get to that after my base review.  The game is great. It's not exactly Company of Heroes 1, and the time between releases shows, but for the most part, the improvements are positive ones. I absolutely love the addition of TrueSight, as it makes the feel of the game much more realistic and provides a much greater opportunity for basic tactical gameplay. The first time someone slips a Panzer IV around you without you noticing and starts harrassing one of your flanks, you will feel it's impact.  The campaign is a little lackluster, but still good. I didn't find myself quite as drawn into it as I was with the original game, and around halfway through I sort of lost interest. Those of you who are considering buying the game for that merit alone might want to consider waiting for a steam sale or something.  Multiplayer is improved, with a much more streamlined way of finding exactly what kind of match you want. I haven't messed around with it too much, but it seems reasonably effective at matching players of equal skill level, which is always nice.  All in all, I would recommend the game, as it is.  Now, that being said, the other issue. DLC. I don't know who exactly came up with this scheme, but gone is the 'expansion pack' DLC that I loved from the first game. This game is RIDDLED with microtransactions, dozens of paint jobs for vehicles, which could be excusable, but also a huge selection of Commanders, this iterations version of skill trees from the previous game. They pump advertising for this microtransaction ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t into the main menu, and it stays with you no matter what screen you're looking at. I really, really hope this idea dies in it's cradle like the abomination that it is. And, had I known this was going to be the case, it would have been enough for me to forgoe purchasing the game alltogether. It's that bad.  It's the equivalent of finding that girl you had a crush on in high school, 10 years later on the side of the road, turning tricks for a quick 20 bucks. It's just sad and leaves a bad taste in your mouth.

I really enjoy this game! A lot of depth on the fields since you can choose which 'Doctrine' or 'Commander' you want to go with every game. This changes your approach every game so it takes a while to start feeling this RTS repetition syndrome where you get bored of playing a new 20-60min game over and over again. There are two major things I could point out on the bad side. First thing is that 'Doctrines' are limited at the begining. Even after playing for a while you beging to think it's a bit limited. Then, you see there are lot's of DLC where you get new ones. They released TONS of them and still are releasing new ones. Sometimes it kind of sucks to have to buy new ones but if you want to keep up against other players online you will have to at some point. As for my second point, I personally think that heavy tanks are a bit of a pain to get rid of with some nations/doctrines. In fact, if you let your opponent get started on a tank spam, it's probably impossible to stop them. Anything giving an edge to the opponent, gets them snowballing so hard that getting back on track is almost never possible exept if they make a big mistake over the course of their destructive push.  Overall, this game is very entertaining and gives RTS types of game a bit of hope. The lifetime of this game is really interestingly long if you take the time to learn every gamestyles. The campaign is fun and takes a good amount of time to finish even as a RTS experienced player.

Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy game for people who don't like RTS games. And I don't mean that in a dismissive or condescending way.   COH2 does away with resource-collecting. Borrowing from Relic's own Dawn of War series of games, in COH2, resources are automatically allocated over time based on the number of strategic points each team controls. Want to build tanks? You better keep an eye on that fuel cache, lest it falls into enemy hands!  Gone also are most base management options: instead, the factions have various 'battle phases' which can be built in any order and require a certain amount of resources to unlock. When said 'battle phases' are completed, they unlock additional units like artillery, mechanized infantry and tanks.  The result is a constant fight for strategic points and to push back into enemy territories. Building a large army is not as important as micromanaging units (is my infantry behind cover? are they exposed to mortar fire? can the enemy sneak up behind my back?) and adapting to the ever-changing landscape of war. A swarm of StuG III medium tanks is deadly indeed, but it can be obliterated in an instant by a handful of strategically-placed anti-tank guns, or a carefully aimed artillery strike. And no matter how strong the Oberkommando's Sturmpioneer infantry can be in close quarters combat situations, they are no match for a machine gun nest or light vehicle fire, making them a potentially costly gamble when used against a skilled opponent.  Every faction has different units, commanders and build orders, so everyone can find a faction that suits their play style. Americans have highly-trained and well-equipped infantry, and can parachute behind enemy lines. The Soviets lack training and equipment, but they make up for it with unrivaled amounts of manpower and fairly cheap tanks. The British excel behind cover, and they build strong defensive emplacements such as mortars pits and anti-aircraft guns to fend off the enemy. The German Wehrmacht is a well-balanced army of skilled infantry and strong vehicles. And finally, the Oberkommando have access to less resources than the other factions but they are nomads on the battlefield, relying on stronger and more versatile vehicles that are more costly but simply unmatched in terms of strength.  Best of all, the tide of battle can turn in an instant even very late in the game if you build up your troops wisely and use the element of surprise to your advantage. An overconfident enemy can lose the battle mere seconds away from victory if you start mass producing heavy tanks, or you disrupt his supply lines, or you call in air support on the frontline, or you make one last desperate push towards the control points.  In other words, Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy game that feels like an action game with a top-down view. It's not Age of Empires with a World War II skin on top of it. This isn't StarCraft either: it's not a game for pianists who can press 300 keys per minutes. It's a game of cooperation, military strategy and wit.

To be honest, as a legacy player, I feel cheated by the devs and their MP DLC system, which primarily focuses on introducing new players (we legacy players paid $60 for the game, the new guys can play for $10), but since recommending is for new players anyway, I'll vote to recommend this game.  Let's see. First things first, despite everything, I really like this game. It's a nice mix of realism and gameplay value, creating something that's not overly complicated, but does add some basic immersion to the game. Does it have a greedy money-driven system? Of course. Game devs need money. Is it the most realistic RTS on the market? No, but its a fun and functional product (as long as your internet and PC are up to standards).  For the nitty-gritty people who want to know more than just the basics, let's look at the specific pros and cons:  +A great, ever-changing multiplayer experience - not a very repetitive game +Good mechanics that allow for a basic sense of immersion without comprimising overall 'fun value' +It is possible to hold your ground without buying any of the infamous DLC commanders +Through the drop system it is also possible to access the DLC commanders with just playtime +Unique standalone MP expansions that allow full features for a fraction of the price +Ardennes Assault (although pricey) is a great SP campaign +Great voice acting and good-looking graphics +Developers keep game up-to-date +A growing modding community that keeps getting better and better +Steam Workshop content is showcased for competitive ladder-climbing every now and then  -Modding community has limited access to assets. It's impressive how much they've made with so little. -Skewed matchmaking: when searching for a MP match, Allies consist of 30% or less, and Axis 70% or more -Armored warfare mechanics are highly arcadish and unrealistic that occasionally ruin immersion -Vehicle pathing issues that have not been fully resolved despite the game being out for about 2 years -Balance issues still haven't been worked out completely either. The balance team is juggling patches (kudos to them) but some rather mindless 'blobbing/spamming' tactics have yet to be fully addressed (looking at you, P. Gren spam). -Obvious anti-Soviet sentiment in the base SP campaign. Focuses around the atrocities of the Red Army instead of its heroism. Not saying the Red Army is made of angels, but the showcased Soviet brutality in the campaign were isolated events that happened very rarely. The devs had some nerve naming the Soviets 'protagonists' in the campaign.  +/-Some rather mind-blowing RNG that (unfortunately) is to be expected of any game where realism plays any role +/-Unrealistic weapon statistics in exchange for some semblance of balance (that as I said before, isn't quite balanced as it should be). Not a big deal for most people, but for a WWII buff like me it really bothers me that the weapons don't accurately reflect and represent their real-life counterparts. Can be fixed by modding. +/-DLC system tends to disenhearten legacy or veteran players that bought the game at release, but, if you are looking to get into CoH2, congrats. This is a plus for you then. +/-Not nearly as realistic or mechanic-heavy as Men of War: Assault Squad II, which is a $30 RTS with 5 nations rather than 4, but MP is actually fully functional and therefore infintely more stable. Pick your poison.  Is it best-in-class? Not exactly. But a game doesn't have to be better than all of its competition to be considered good. I like the game, I look forward to the new British Faction (but my wallet doesn't...) and I hope the devs someday will release more powerful modding tools. Would I recommend this game to a new player? The MP standalone armies: yes, the base $40 game: no (unless you really /really/ REALLY want to play as Ostheer or Soviets). For $10-$15, you can't get a better RTS multiplayer experience.  And that's my 100% completely honest review of this game.  PS: Do not try automatched ladder play when traveling abroad. They don't seem to have region-specific servers, and this could lead to unsatisfactory win-loss ratios coupled with a lot of rage. I learned the hard way: I dropped from rank 6,000ish (top 33%) to rank 15,000ish (bottom 33%) on the 1v1 Soviet ladder in a matter of days by playing the game in China rather than the US due to extreme lag or disconnects.

Recommending this game because it really isn't that bad, but I MUST voice some slight disappointments. For example:  -No doctrines. This was the single GREATEST feature of CoH. I was really hoping that the Germans would restore their old doctrines (possibly with the defense doctrine improved as it sucked a*s). Russians would get doctrines focusing on mass attack, inferior armor in massive numbers, or a propaganda doctrine that increased resources and passively grants Russians more power in friendly territory. I really hope they reintroduce doctrines in the third game.  -Resource caps. Another detriment to the game. Back in the first CoH, resources would accumulate... well, forever, really. It would allow for epic infantry assaults (one American Rifleman squad costs 270 manpower in that game, so having 2000 manpower was truly great), or slow accumulation of more upgrades for your army (to purchase flamethrowers, it cost 50 ammo, or 75 for a Grenadier's Panzershrek). The limits are set to 1,500 for manpower, 500 for munitions, and I THINK 250 for fuel. I also hope they remove this from the third game.  -Overly complicated UI. The first CoH was SO simple and very easy to get into. When I began to play this game, it confused me at first. Everything became smaller... and not so easy to understand. Devs may have put too many things on the screen, and I hope they resimplify the UI like it was back in CoH.  -TOO. MUCH. FREAKING. DLCs. Enough said. Pretty much it. The game has depth, it's not too boring, and I think you'll like it.

Let's just get one thing clear up front. No. It is not as good as the original Company of Heroes.  Why?  It's the little things. To put it simply, where COH1 felt like an RTS equivalent of a classic war movie, COH2 feels gamey, seeming to cater exclusively to multiplayer. I've watched submachinegunners firing entire clips at point blank range into artillery crews who just stand there, not dying for what feels like an eternity. Where in COH1 you could build sandbag walls and tank traps and barbed wire that seemed to fit seemlessly into their surroundings, player structures in COH2 stand out like a sore thumb. Sure it's a little more streamlined to have a fixed structure you place that serves its purpose, but it just doesn't feel as immersive as something that looks like something you'd actually see on the battlefield. I could go on about how increadibly long it takes to kill a tank while other units can be wiped out by one mortar round but I'll stop myself.  The campaign is reasonably fun but feels overly political. I mean, I'm pretty anti-communist myself but a lot of the attrocities depicted in the campaign are just depicted in a way that makes the bad communist commissar look more like a cartoon villain than a genuinely evil person. It's all just so ridiculous that it's hard to actually care when something awful happens.   COH2 isn't, for all this, a bad game by any means. It's still my favorite basic model for an RTS and in many ways it does improve on COH1. The graphics are better. The sound is better, particularly when your camera is far from the action and the sounds of your units fighting on different parts of the map mesh together to create an ambient battlefield sound that is immesely fun to listen to. COH2 also features a fun mission mode which can be a nice break from the simple, straightforward skirmish.   In the end this game just barely warrents a 3/5 from me. It's a definite step down from COH1 for the franchise but it's still a solid game that, were it not for the legacy of its predecessor would be truly amazing.  RECOMENDATION: Wait for a 66%-75% off sale.

For seconds, the game is a rampant money grab, everything is for sale, uniforms, badges for the main menu, hell, you can buy a silver or bronze border for a dollar. Just to give you a clue, the total expenditure (not including the game itself) on packs could be up to $212?! I think it's easily possible to spend over $300 on this. Whatever you do, don't do it...  And perhaps most importantly, the core gameplay seems like more of the same, but...somehow less (probably due to the lack of Americans and German factions). Due to the ham fisted story, the game wants you to throw men forward to slaughter, just to prove how brutal to their own soldiers the Russians were in WW2.  Somehow COH has lost it's soul, and lost it's way. I wonder if the publisher Sega had anything to do with that? Most likely...  UPDATE: So, after a lot of playing I think my final anlysis is this: The game is still a big money grab, content that should be free has to be paid for. The multiplayer is better than the original, only in the sense that in the original I lost every time, but COH2 seems more balanced (despite imbalances), and at least I can win sometimes now! :) Overall, I have changed it to a thumbs up, because the positives outweigh the negatives, but I still think the DLC format sucks, and that a campaign for UK & GY would have been good.
